html:
Apr 14 (IFR)

  • Tristar Transport cancels IPO on last day 
  • 468 SPAC targets €300m Frankfurt float
  • Katek targets €80m float for roll-up strategy
  • Dustin backs Centralpoint buy with SKr1.2bn rights issue
  • Deutsche Beteiligungs to fund pipeline with €105m capital increase
  • Final terms for Nexity
  • Airtel Africa sale totals £37.5m

UAE energy logistics business Tristar Transport threw in the towel late on Wednesday for an up to Dh647m (US$176m) Dubai float, blaming market conditions.

A banker involved said that the recent weakening in sentiment towards new issues had not been helpful, especially for a small deal outside of core geographies in a business that is not as focused on growth as much of the rest of the pipeline.

The deal had been due to wrap up today, with share trading planned for April 22.

It would have been the first UAE IPO since Al Mal Capital REIT’s Dh350m listing in January.

Bank of America and Citigroup were joint global coordinators, with First Abu Dhabi Bank as joint regional coordinator, lead manager and joint bookrunner. HSBC was also joint regional coordinator and joint bookrunner, with SocieteGenerale as joint bookrunner and Marcaz as co-lead manager.

Berenberg is sole bookrunner on the €300m Frankfurt float of 468 SPAC, which will target a business in marketplaces, direct-to-consumer or software and artificial intelligence in Europe, the US or Switzerland.

The trio of well-known German tech entrepreneurs behind Berlin-based investment company 468 Capital is the main draw for investors.

Early feedback has been "overwhelmingly positive" due to the expertise of Alexander Kudlich, Ludwig Ensthaler and FlorianLeibert, who founded the deep tech-focused investment firm.

A management roadshow launched on Wednesday for what will be the second SPAC to list in Germany after LakestarSPAC raised €275m in February. Bookbuilding for 468 SPAC is likely to be speedy, according to a banker involved.

Kudlich, an angel investor in the likes of HelloFresh, DeliveryHero and Global Fashion Group, worked alongside Ensthaler at Rocket Internet, and Leibert is a California-based angel investor.

A total of 300m units will be offered at €10 each, with a unit representing one class A share and one-third of a class A warrant. The exercise price is €11.50.

Warrants can be exercised from 30 days after completion of a business combination and until five years later. They are redeemable if there is a significant premium to the exercise price or if the company offers the possibility of a "make-whole exercise", which will be outlined in prospectus.

468 Capital will invest in 7.5m class B warrants to finance offering expenses and working capital, amounting to 20% of the offering size. They will be converted into class A shares after completion of a deal.

The sponsor will be locked up for one year after the business combination, or earlier if shares trade above €12 for any 20 trading days in a 30-day period.

Lakestar SPAC is backed by German venture capitalist Klaus Hommels. It raised €275m in a Frankfurt float on February 22.

Shares in Lakestar have gradually traded down, but have remained above IPO pricing of €10. They peaked at €12.32 on February 23, and closed on Wednesday at €10.32 each.

German electronics business Katek is targeting €80m in a Frankfurt IPO, with proceeds to fund acceleration of growth, including acquisitions.

Parent Primepulse, which failed to float for €250m in late 2018, is not selling in the base deal but will provide the greenshoe and retain its majority ownership.

Katek provides software and hardware development, prototyping and manufacture of electronics, with customers in e-mobility, automotive, internet of things, renewable energy and medical technology.

The company has more than 2,600 employees in Germany and Eastern Europe.

Katek will focus its acquisition strategy on Germany, Austria and Switzerland and expects to make two acquisitions per year.

The float is effectively a roll-up story in a similar vein to German IT services business Cancom, which raised €174m in a December 2019 IPO to finance bolt-on acquisitions, and was also a Primepulse investment. There are no obvious peers.

The company has increased sales to €414m in 2020, up 59% from €261m in 2019, and up from €164m in 2018. In 2020, Ebitda increased 5% to €20.8m, with a medium-term target of 10%, and 93% of revenues were generated from regular customers. Leverage was approximately 2.45x with €51m of net debt.

Primepulse has an 81% pre-money position, with 10% held by fellow investor GrossoTec, with the balance held by management and minority shareholders.

The free-float is expected to be approximately 33%, suggesting a market capitalisation of €242m.

An accelerated schedule of around two weeks should see pricing before the end of April. The float has drawn interest from earlier pilot-fishing rounds.

Hauck & Aufhauser is sole global coordinator and joint bookrunner with MM Warburg. Hauck & Aufhauser ran the Cancom listing and was joint global coordinator alongside Deutsche Bank on the earlier Primepulse attempted IPO.

Swedish IT reseller Dustin Group is planning a SKr1.2bn (US$141m) capital increase after completion of the €425m acquisition of Belgian hardware and software reseller Centralpoint Holding, which operates in the Benelux region.

The initial cash payment will be covered by a bridge loan from Swedbank, followed by the rights issue and some debt issuance. The debt could be a loan or bond and is expected in the second half of the year. Dustin said the acquisition will complement its position in the Netherlands, and is subject to clearance from Dutch competition authorities.

Dustin is issuing 8.25m new shares to Centralpoint’s owner, Rotla, to cover SKr764m of the acquisition cost.

Shareholders will vote at an EGM on May 18 on whether to approve the rights issue, intended to be completed in the second half of 2021.

Dustin’s two largest shareholders Axel Johnson and AMF Fonder will vote in favour of the rights issue at the EGM, representing 40% of the votes. Axel Johnson and Rotla will subscribe for their pro rata share of 36% of the rights issue, and AMF said it intends to subscribe pro rata to its 11.6% stake.

Shares were up more than 45% this year as of Monday’s SKr93.25 close, jumping more than 17% by Tuesday’s close on news of the Centralpoint acquisition and strong Q2 numbers showing record earnings. On Wednesday, shares closed down 1.64% at SKr107.70.

Carnegie and Swedbank/Kepler Cheuvreux are joint lead managers for the rights issue, with Carnegie also advising Dustin.

Private equity firm Deutsche Beteiligungs is targeting €105m from a rights issue to finance agreed equity investments and future co-investments.

Deutsche Beteiligungs’ three-year growth strategy envisages an increase in equity investments of approximately 40% compared to the previous three years.

The rights issue comprises 3.76m shares on a 1-for-4 basis at €28 each, a 26.1% discount to TERP of €37.88, based on the €40.35 Monday close. Pricing is a 30.6% discount to the Monday close.

Shareholders representing approximately 22% of share capital have indicated interest in subscribing to the rights issue.

Subscription began on Wednesday and runs until April 27, and rights trading wraps up on April 22. Any rump will be dealt with on April 27.

DBAG shares had risen more than 22% this year as of Friday’s €39.1554 close, but have since fallen. They closed at €37.32 on Tuesday and finished down 3% at €36.20 on Wednesday.

Jefferies and UniCredit/Kepler Cheuvreux are joint bookrunners.

Final terms on Nexity's liability management exercise were out late last night with the developer securing 92.8% of the €270m (principal) outstanding on the 2023 convertible bonds. The French company paid €66.90 per bond, from guidance of €66.60–€66.90. The company raised €240m through a seven-year CB at the same time where the initial conversion price is €59.81.

An institutional investor sold a 1.3% stake in Airtel Africa on Tuesday evening for £37.5m, comprising 50m shares at 75p, an 11.5% discount to the 84.8p close. Airtel Africa stock closed more than 12% down on Wednesday at 74.55p.

JP Morgan was sole bookrunner.

This week’s deals

Monday

Air France-KLM: €190m primary ABB, subject to clawback, increase option of €130m, shares on offer at €4.84 to market close of €5.314 (max discount of 8.9%). Credit Agricole, Deutsche Bank, HSBC, Natixis, Banco Santander, Societe Generale.

Springwater Special Situations (US – SPAC): US$150m Nasdaq IPO, 15m (one share, one-half warrant exercisable at US$11.50) at US$10 per unit, books close April 12. ABN AMRO, EarlyBirdCapital

Tuesday

Nexity (France – Real estate): €240m seven-year convertible bonds (OCEANE), €30m upsize not used, coupon 0.875% (0.375%–0.875%), conv price €59.81, premium 35% (35%–40%, from 40%–45%). BNP Paribas, Credit Agricole, JP Morgan

Thursday

Cellnex (Spain – Telecoms infrastructure): €7bn rights issue, 192.6m on 19-for-48 basis at €36.33 (17% discount to €43.75 TERP), subscription March 1–15, result/rump April 21. Barclays, BNP Paribas, Goldman Sachs, JP Morgan

Tristar Transport (Dubai – Energy logistics): CANCELLED Dh528m–Dh647m (US$144m–US$176m) Dubai Financial Market, 199m (US$120m–$146m) primary, c. 41m secondary, no greenshoe, free-float min. 20%, books April 4–15, pricing April 16, trading April 22. Bank of America, Citigroup, First Abu Dhabi, HSBC, Societe Generale

Pipeline

PENDING – Great Point Entertainment (UK – Fund)

Up to £200m London specialist fund segment IPO, 200m shares at 100p, prospectus February 11, books close March 3, result March 4, trading March 9. N+1 Singer

April 21 – SSP (UK – Food Concessions)

£475m fully underwritten rights issue, 258m (48%) shares at 184p on a 12-for-25 basis, 37.3% discount to TERP of 293.3p, subscription April 7–21, result April 22. Barclays, Goldman Sachs, HSBC, JP Morgan, BNP Paribas, Bank of America, Mediobanca

April 22 – Gore Street Energy Storage Fund (UK)

Up to £197m follow-on, up to 190m shares at 102p (6.2% discount to April 1 close of 108.7p, 2.4% premium to last reported NAV of 99.6p), books April 6–22, result April 23. JP Morgan, Shore Capital

April 22 – Hemnet (Sweden – Property listings)

US$250m–$300m Nasdaq Stockholm all-secondary IPO, books c. April 15–22. Carnegie, Citigroup, Morgan Stanley, Barclays, Nordea

April 27 – Deutsche Beteiligungs (Germany – Investment firm)

€105m rights issue, 3.76m (25%) on 1-for-4 basis at €28 (26.1% discount to €37.88 TERP), subscription April 14–27, rights trading April 14–22, result/rump April 27. Jefferies, UniCredit/Kepler Cheuvreux

April 29 – Impact Healthcare REIT (UK – Care homes)

£50m follow-on, fixed price of 111.5p (2.5% discount to April 1 close of 114.4p, 1.8% premium to last reported NAV of 109.58p), books April 4–29, result April 30. RBC, Winterflood.

April 30 - Katek (Germany – Electronics)

€80m Frankfurt IPO, all primary base, 15% secondary greenshoe. Hauck & Aufhauser, MM Warburg

April – 468 SPAC (Germany)

€300m SPAC IPO, 30m units at €10. Berenberg

April – Allfunds (Netherlands – Wealth management platform)

c. €2bn Euronext Amsterdam IPO, all-secondary, min. 25% free-float, pre-marketing from April 7. BNPParibas, Citigroup, Credit Suisse, Morgan Stanley, Barclays, Bank of America, CaixaBank, HSBC, IMI-IntesaSanpaolo, ING,Santander.

April – Darktrace (UK – Cyber security)

LSE IPO, primary float with secondary greenshoe, pre-marketing from April 12. Berenberg, Jefferies, KKR, Needham & Company, Piper Sandler & Co.

April – Segezha (Russia – Paper production)

Rbs30bn (US$389m) primary and secondary Moscow float, pre-marketing from April 12. JP Morgan, UBS, VTB Capital, Alfa Capital Markets, Bank of America,Renaissance Capital. 

April – SECO (Italy – Technology)

€115m Milan float, 27m primary shares, 10.77m secondary shares, 15% greenshoe, 40%–45% free-float, pre-marketing from April 12. Goldman Sachs, Mediobanca

April – Synlab (Germany – Medical testing)

€400m-plus Frankfurt IPO, €400m primary, undisclosed secondary tranche, pre-marketing from April 7. Goldman Sachs, JP Morgan, Bank of America, Barclays, Deutsche Bank, HSBC, Jefferies, UniCredit.

April – Trustly (Sweden – Payments)

SKr8bn-plus (US$934m) Stockholm IPO, c. €6bn–€9bn valuation estimates, pre-marketing from April 12. Carnegie, Goldman Sachs, JP MorganCitigroup, Bank of America, BNPParibas, Deutsche Bank, SEB, Swedbank/Kepler Cheuvreux, Rabobank.

April – Grupo Ecoener (Spain – Renewables)

Up to €200m all-primary Spanish IPO, 10% primary greenshoe, pre-marketing from April 7. SocieteGenerale, BancoSabadell, Credit Agricole, CaixaBank, HSBC

April – PensionBee (UK – Online Platform)

£60m LSE high growth segment IPO, £55m primary, £5m secondary, pre-marketing from March 30, admission in April. Keefe, Bruyette & Woods

April – Polypeptide (Switzerland – Drug producer)

c. €600m SIX Swiss listing, SFr200m in primary with undisclosed secondary tranche, valuation c. €1.5bn, pre-marketing from April 12. Bank of America, Credit Suisse, Morgan Stanley, Berneberg, Danske Bank, ZKB 

April – OPDenergy (Spain – Renewables)

€417m IPO, €400m primary, €17m secondary, pre-marketing from April 8. Citigroup, Santander, Alantra, Bank of America, Berenberg, Royal Bank of Canada. Evercore, Rothschild advising

April – EuroHold (Bulgaria – Holding company)

Lv197.5m (US$121m) rights issue, 79m at Lv2.50, April 10 EGM.

April – Piraeus Financial Holding (Greece – Bank)

€1bn capital increase, EGM April 7. Goldman Sachs, UBS advising

April – Pegasus Europe (SPAC)

Amsterdam IPO of several hundred million euros, sponsors Tikehau Capital, Financiere Agache, Jean Pierre Mustier, Diego De Giorgi. Citigroup, JP Morgan

May 6 – US Solar Fund

c. US$105m placing and offer for subscription at US$1, offer for subscription May 5, placing May 6, result May 7. Cenkos, Jefferies

June – Vallourec (France – Steel tubes)

€300m capital increase backstopped by lenders and bondholders, approval at EGM in April.

TBD – NextEnergy Renewables (UK – Fund)

c. £300m London IPO, 300m shares at 100p, books February 15–March 4, on hold March 4. JP Morgan, Kempen

H1 – JP Morgan Global Core Real Assets (UK)

£80m-plus placing, offer for subscription and intermediaries offer at 100p, timetable due before summer 2021. JP Morgan

H2 – Oxford Nanopore (UK – DNA sequencing)

LSE IPO, IP Group 15% stake valued at £340.3m.

H2 2021 – Dustin Group (Sweden – IT reseller)
SKr1.2bn (US$141m) rights issue, May 18 EGM, c. 36%-47.6% shareholder backing.

2021 – Keliber (Finland – Lithium mining)

Helsinki IPO. Carnegie, Nordea

2021 – Giochi Preziosi (Italy – Toys)

IPO. Banca Akros, Banca IMI, Barclays, Jefferies, Santander (Rothschild advising)
